student_responses:
In this age of political polarization and partisanship, the assumption that incumbents need more votes to win is a dangerous one. This belief perpetuates the notion that the status quo is superior to change, and that the voice of a minority is not worthy of representation. However, evidence shows that this belief is not only flawed but also dangerous.
One of the most compelling arguments against the incumbent advantage is the fact that it gives an unfair advantage to those who are already in power. When incumbents are allowed to campaign for more votes than their opponents, it creates a sense of legitimacy that can be difficult to overcome. This advantage can also lead to complacency, as incumbents may become arrogant and unresponsive to the needs of their constituents.
Another argument against the incumbent advantage is the fact that it can lead to a lack of diversity in politics. If incumbents are allowed to campaign for more votes than challengers, it is unlikely that there will be a large pool of candidates who are willing to run against them. This can lead to a lack of diversity in political representation, as only those who are able and willing to campaign receive the attention they need.
Finally, the incumbent advantage can lead to a lack of accountability for incumbents. If incumbents are allowed to campaign for more votes than challengers, it can be difficult to hold them accountable for their actions. This can lead to a lack of transparency and accountability in government, as incumbents may be able to avoid scrutiny and criticism.
In conclusion, the belief that incumbents need more votes to win is a dangerous one that perpetuates the status quo and leads to a lack of accountability and diversity in politics. Instead, we should work to create a political system that is fair and equitable, where the voice of the people is heard and their needs are represented. This can be achieved by reforming campaign finance laws, ensuring that all candidates are given equal coverage, and promoting greater transparency and accountability in government.

Title: Moral Morality vs. Legal Morality

Moral and legal morality are two distinct concepts that are often confused. Morality is defined as the principles and values that guide human behavior, while law is the set of rules and regulations that govern how people interact with each other. It is widely agreed that some actions that are considered immoral are not necessarily illegal. For example, whistleblowing, which exposes corruption and wrongdoing, is considered immoral but not illegal in many jurisdictions. Similarly, actions that promote free speech and civil liberties, such as protest and assembly, are also considered immoral but not illegal. These actions may go against traditional moral frameworks but are still legal and protected under the constitution. In contrast, actions that harm others, such as violence and theft, are always illegal, regardless of their moral implications. The role of personal freedom and the limits of government in regulating morality are critical in determining whether a particular action is moral or immoral. While the government has the power to regulate immoral actions through laws, it must also balance its power with the limits of individuals' freedom to express their views.
